channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: The similar paths to radicalization in foiled Taylor Swift concert attack, New Orleans carnage
item.description: A troubling pattern of self-radicalization has emerged, experts and intelligence officials say, with the Islamic State’s online presence grooming would-be terrorists around the world.

item.title: Judge upholds Trump’s felony conviction in New York, schedules sentencing for Jan. 10, days before presidential inauguration
item.description: Donald Trump, the only former president ever charged with crimes, argued that his election in November to another term meant the judge should toss his conviction for falsifying business records to conceal a payment to adult-film actress Stormy Daniels.

item.title: Mike Johnson reelected as House speaker after some GOP holdouts change votes. Follow our coverage.
item.description: Louisiana Republican Mike Johnson was reelected House speaker Friday on the first vote, overcoming skepticism about his leadership from some in his party. Johnson clinched the post after lawmakers who initially voted against him changed their votes. President-elect Donald Trump endorsed Johnson this week and urged Republican lawmakers to back him, in part so that the party could move quickly to enact Trump’s agenda.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: My daughter-in-law cut me off over my son’s secret child
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: My daughter-in-law cut me off over my son’s secret child

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Surgeon general urges cancer warning labels for alcohol and a reassessment of recommended limits of consumption
item.description: In an advisory, Vivek H. Murthy said alcohol consumption is the third leading preventable cause of cancer in the United States and contributes to 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 related deaths each year. The warning label would need to be approved by Congress. It’s unclear how the next administration would handle the recommendation.

item.title: New Orleans attack. Cybertruck driver. U.S. Steel. House speaker. Jan. 6 mystery. Hot 2024. Daylight saving. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Biden decides to block U.S. Steel sale to Japanese buyer, administration officials say
item.description: The move threatens the future of the once-iconic American business and is expected as early as Friday, according to two administration officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

item.title: Years of inaction on ‘crisis’ at the Secret Service set the stage for the Trump rally shooting, Post review finds
item.description: Three presidents and Congress failed to fix major vulnerabilities in the Secret Service that were identified a decade ago, contributing to an exodus of veteran agents that has left the service increasingly relying on less experienced members, including at the now-infamous Butler, Pennsylvania, rally where Donald Trump was nearly killed.

item.title: Biden plans to create two national monuments in California honoring tribes
item.description: The Chuckwalla and Sáttítla national monuments would safeguard landscapes that Native American tribes have revered for thousands of years. The designations would come just weeks before President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration.

item.title: Tesla Cybertruck explosion outside Trump hotel in Las Vegas was likely a suicide, sheriff says
item.description: Las Vegas Sheriff Kevin McMahill said at a news conference Thursday that the investigation indicates the driver sustained a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head before the Cybertruck’s explosion. He said one of the guns found in the vehicle was located at the driver’s feet.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Husband claims he doesn’t ‘know how’ to pack lunch for their kid
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Husband claims he doesn’t ‘know how’ to pack lunch for their kid

item.title: New Orleans truck attacker acted alone, FBI says, countering previous statements about potential accomplices
item.description: The attacker was seen on surveillance footage placing two improvised explosive devices in the area before the pickup truck attack, an FBI official said at a news conference Thursday. He added that at this point, there is no definitive link between events in New Orleans and Las Vegas, where a Cybertruck exploded in front of the Trump hotel.

item.title: Our week-long Year in Review is almost over. Play today’s On the Record now.
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: New Orleans attack. Cybertruck explosion. Chinese hack. Liz Cheney. Snow forecast. Justin Baldoni. Yellowstone. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Treasury Department’s sanctions office hacked by Chinese government, officials say
item.description: The targeting of the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) as well as the Office of the Treasury Secretary reflects Beijing’s determination to acquire intelligence on its most significant rival in the global competition for power and influence, U.S. officials said.

item.title: Tonight’s Sugar Bowl has been postponed 24 hours to Thursday night after the deadly New Orleans truck attack
item.description: The Sugar Bowl, a New Orleans tradition, will be the last of four quarterfinal games in the newly expanded College Football Playoff. The game between Georgia and Notre Dame will be played under heightened security on Thursday night, officials said, after a truck attack at 3:15 a.m. Wednesday that killed at least 10 and injured dozens. The FBI said that it is investigating the attack as an act of terrorism and that authorities think the suspect, Shamsud-Din Jabbar, did not act alone.

item.title: Suspected driver in New Orleans attack identified as U.S. citizen with an ISIS flag, weapons and potential IED in his truck
item.description: The FBI said authorities were investigating the attack, which killed at least 10 and injured dozens, as an act of terrorism. They identified the driver as Shamsud-Din Jabbar, a 42-year-old U.S. citizen from Texas. He was declared dead after a shootout with police. Investigators found an ISIS flag in the vehicle he was driving, along with additional weapons and a possible improvised explosive device, the FBI said.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Losing patience with all these ‘overly nice’ people
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Losing patience with all these ‘overly nice’ people

item.title: What strange things could 2025 have in store? Take David Ignatius’s quiz to find out.
item.description: Can you tell “humint” and “rumint” apart from straight-up nonsense?

item.title: Happy New Year! Play today’s On the Record now.
item.description: Answer now to earn your first points of 2025.

item.title: Driver of truck that killed 10 in New Orleans is dead, FBI says. Attack is being investigated as an act of terrorism.
item.description: The FBI said the driver of the vehicle that plowed into a crowd on Bourbon Street at 3:15 a.m. "engaged with law enforcement" after the attack and is now dead. No further details were available. At an early morning news conference, officials gave conflicting information about whether the attack was an act of terrorism.

item.title: Man rammed pickup truck into New Orleans crowd to create ‘carnage,’ killing 10, official says. He fired on police after crashing.
item.description: New Orleans Police Superintendent Anne Kirkpatrick said a man tried “to run over as many people as he possibly could” in the incident on Bourbon Street overnight.

item.title: 10 killed, 30 injured in New Orleans as vehicle plows into crowd, city officials say
item.description: The emergency preparedness agency of New Orleans said the mass casualty incident took place in the Bourbon Street area overnight.

item.title: 9/11 plea deals. Russian gas. ‘Gone Girl’ charges. Stock rally. Cruise outbreaks. College football. Poisoned goat. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Following up on the stories that moved us in 2024: A penguin love story, a law student and baby, life after ‘Love Is Blind’
item.description: In a seemingly never-ending news cycle, Post reporters took a step back and revisited the stories that made headlines in our region this year. Some were entertaining, some were tragic, and some were just odd.

item.title: 2024 was a great year for the S&P 500. See how the market bet on AI hopes, a Fed policy change, the election and bitcoin.
item.description: The S&P 500 ended 2024 up more than 23 percent for the year, carried in the first half by the “Magnificent Seven” stocks: Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia and Tesla. They were joined in the last few months by a broader market rally, as the Federal Reserve started cutting interest rates and Donald Trump won the November election.

item.title: Covert killings reveal the contours of an ambitious Indian assassination program
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has cast himself as more willing to take on India’s enemies beyond its borders than any other leader since independence. India’s intelligence agency, the Research and Analysis Wing, has since 2021 deployed a methodical assassination program to kill at least a half-dozen people deep within Pakistan, according to Pakistani and Western officials.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: She can organize the bachelorette but can’t stand up with the bride
item.description: Carolyn Hax: She can organize the bachelorette but can’t stand up with the bride

item.title: The Olympics, Notre Dame and pandas: Here are 24 good things that happened in 2024
item.description: We will remember these silver linings going into the New Year.

item.title: The List: What’s out and what’s in for 2025
item.description: Nepo babies. Nepo in-laws. Celebrity look-alike contests. Celebrity digital replica laws. A Post tradition since 1978, The List reveals the present and predicts the future.

item.title: It’s the last day of 2024! Fittingly, our Year in Review continues in today’s On the Record.
item.description: Answer now to earn your points.

item.title: U.S. strikes Houthi targets in Yemen in escalating campaign
item.description: The U.S. military carried out fresh airstrikes against Houthi targets in Yemen, the U.S. Central Command said Tuesday, the latest in an escalating campaign against the Iran-backed militants by Israel and its allies.

item.title: Treasury hack. Trump appeal. Carter funeral. Crash investigation. Norovirus. Arctic blast. Chess drama. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: ‘Baby in a dumpster’: A spate of abandoned newborns unsettles Texas
item.description: Though the state was the first in the country to pass a safe haven law allowing parents to relinquish newborns at designated places, such “Baby Moses” surrenders remain rare here, and a recent series of abandoned babies in the Houston area has prompted much soul-searching.

item.title: U.S. Treasury says it was hacked by China-backed actor, according to a letter reviewed by The Post
item.description: The department was notified on Dec. 8 by a third-party software provider that a hacker gained access to a security key that allowed them to override certain security protocols and access unclassified documents stored on them, according to the letter.

item.title: Jimmy Carter’s funeral to be held Jan. 9 inside the Washington National Cathedral. He will then be buried in Plains, Georgia.
item.description: President Joe Biden issued an executive order stating that all departments and agencies of the federal government will be closed on Jan. 9, which he has declared a national day of mourning for the 39th president. Check back for more details.

item.title: How ridiculous was 2024? Dave Barry's year in review.
item.description: How many goofs can one nation endure? The answer is Boeing in the wind.

item.title: A plot in paradise and India’s struggle for influence in Asia
item.description: Indian agents and politicians in the Maldives held secret contacts over removing its pro-China president. The plot and its backstory offer a rare view into the much broader, often shadowy competition between India and China for dominance in a strategic swath of Asia and its surrounding waters.

item.title: Trump endorses Mike Johnson for reelection as House speaker ahead of perilous vote
item.description: The backing from the president-elect is expected to shore up support among wavering Republicans when the chamber votes on Friday. In a social media post, Trump said that Johnson (R-Louisiana) is “a good, hard working, religious man” and that he has his “total endorsement.”

item.title: How much do you remember about the news in 2024?
item.description: Part 2 of our week-long Year in Review quiz kicks off in today's On the Record.

item.title: Jimmy Carter. Funeral plans. Plane crash. Trump and Musk. Deadly tornadoes. Food dye. Robot surgeries. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: 11 facts about Jimmy Carter that may surprise you
item.description: The peanut farmer-turned-president, who died Sunday at 100, put solar panels on the White House and once spent 89 seconds inside a melting nuclear reactor.

item.title: Jimmy Carter dies at 100, his son says. The 39th president led an extraordinary life that included a Nobel Peace Prize.
item.description: The tenacious Southerner was turned out of office by disillusioned voters after a single term. But Carter had a brilliant post-presidential career as a champion of health, peace and democracy. His wife of 77 years, Rosalynn, died in November 2023.

item.title: Turmoil in Trudeau’s government draws taunts from Trump
item.description: As Canada’s government melts down, President-elect Donald Trump has taken to mocking embattled Prime Minister Justin Trudeau as the “governor” of the “great state of Canada” in middle-of-the-night social media posts.

item.title: The laughs, heartbreaks and hopes of 2024
item.description: When we look back on 2024, it’s easy for the campaign and the election to drown out everything else that happened. But there was so much more!

item.title: Israel built an ‘AI factory’ for war. It unleashed it in Gaza.
item.description: Years before the Gaza war, Israel transformed its intelligence unit into an AI testing ground. A Washington Post investigation reveals previously unreported details of the inner workings of the program, along with the secretive, decade-long history of its development.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Nearly all 181 on plane that crashed in South Korea presumed dead, fire agency says
item.description: The Jeju Air flight was coming from Bangkok when it crashed at Muan International Airport, according to officials. Two were rescued.
